w:r.w:t: An Overview of Natural Language Processing
After completing this chapter, the readers are expected to
Gain knowledge about various semantic and syntactic paradigms in NLP
Learn the basics of Neural Networks
Become familiar with the evaluation metrics employed in neural network

The natural evolution of languages has enabled humans to communicate and share ideas across geopolitical boundaries. However, the concept of a machine processing and understanding these human languages is a complex challenge. Since machines inherently understand numbers and numerical operations, it is necessary to convert natural language into a format that computers can comprehend. This is where NLP comes into play. NLP is an interdisciplinary
within computer science that encompasses techniques to make human language accessible and
by machines. The foundational concepts in NLP draw from a wide range of disciplines, including theoretical computer science, linguistics, statistics, and artif
Statistical methods and linear machine learning models have long been

in NLP tasks. However, these traditional approaches depend heavily on manually crafted dictionaries and features, limiting their capacity to capture complex patterns and semantics in language. As the volume of textual data has increased and computational resources have become more accessible, neural architectures have gained prominence in modern NLP techniques. These neural models excel at capturing
from data, processing inputs of varying lengths, leveraging information from long sequences of text, and autonomously learning features, reducing the need for extensive manual e
This chapter is divided into two parts. In
the goals of computational linguistics and NLP. Section 2.2 describes various tasks in NLP and introduces the NLP pipeline.
Section 2.3 explores the linguistic components of language, such as
. In Section 2.4, we provide an overview of di

and semantic analysis techniques. Section 2.5 focuses on syntax and grammar-based parsing methods, while Section 2.6 delves into semantics and semantic parsing. Finally, Section 2.7 presents the task of language
we explore neural networks and related concepts to set the foundation for deep learning techniques discussed in later chapters. Section 2.8 introduces the perceptron and its application
er. Section 2.9 presents multilayer perceptrons and popular non
linear activation functions. Section 2.10 covers the gradient-based training process for neural networks and error backpropagation. In
uence neural network training. Section 2.11 focuses on the challenges that af
ect gradient descent. Finally, in Section 2.12, we examine the performance measures commonly used to evaluate deep learning tasks.
Since the advent of computers, researchers have been captivated by the idea of teaching machines to interact like humans. As early as 1963, Joseph
designed to converse with humans. Fast forward to 2014, Eugene Goostman, a
, with human judges unable to discern that Eugene was, in fact, a
by introducing a new machine translation architecture, now famously known as

More recently, the success and widespread adoption of language models like ChatGPT, and its successors have generated immense interest in language models, accelerating research in both NLP and deep learning. This book is motivated by the need to enhance our understanding of language models and to demystify the concepts from beginner to advanced levels.
omputation aside, a very nuanced problem with language is its ambiguity, contextuali
nature relative to the zeitgeist. Consider the sentence ‘

’. One interpretation could be that I saw a duck (noun) that belonged to her. Another interpretation of this same sentence could be that I saw her perform the act of ducking (verb) to avoid an obstacle. Depending on the context, sentences with similar structures and subjects can still convey very dif
erent meanings. Take the following sentences: ‘
I ate rice with a spoon
All of these sentences convey that I am eating rice. In the f

rst instance, I use a spoon as a utensil, while in the second sentence, I use curd as an accompaniment. The third sentence, however, suggests that I am eating rice in the presence of a person. Teaching computers to understand how to interpret these sentences di
ferently and resolve ambiguities has been a signif
cant motivation behind the development of
Computational Linguistics and Natural Language Processin
Like any other medium of information, human languages have undergone various stages of development
they originated at some point in time, propagated far and wide, and have borne witness to the evolution of human society. While we do not know exactly when and
how the earliest humans spoke, numerous theories have been proposed about the origin of language. Alister Hardy and Elaine Morgan proposed the

in 1997, highlighting that there are certain traits we do not share with our primate relatives but that we do share communication traits with aquatic animals. For example, whales and dolphins are known to communicate with members of their species using sounds.
Linguistics is the discipline that engages in the scientif
c study of languages. It is an interdisciplinary system (
Figure 2.1) where linguistics and its branches, such as sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, and neurolinguistics, seek to answer signif
cant philosophical questions, such as: What rules do languages follow? How do languages evolve? How do we learn and process meanings in our minds? How are dif
erent modalities of languages related to each other? Linguists like Noam Chomsky and Steven Pinker hypothesi

e that language is something innate. From a very early age, we begin to mimic natural sounds and lip movements. We grow up associating these sounds with certain objects, qualities, and attributes of the environment around us. By studying these theories, we can infer what the earliest languages might have been like, but our understanding only extends so far back into the history of human languages (Jurafsky and Martin 2009; Pinker 2010; Vaneechoutte 2014).

igure 2.1: Language-related Disciplines (Tsujii 2021) – Linguistics, Cognitive Science, Psychology, Natural Language Processing (NLP), Artificial Intelligence (AI), and Computational Linguistics. All of these disciplines study language from different perspectives
and psychology, also show great interest in languages. Computational linguistics is a sub-f
eld of both linguistics and computer science that focuses on the interactions between human language and computers, serving as a bridge between the broader
of linguistics and engineering processes. While computational linguistics is more concerned with understanding language structure and developing computational models, NLP
the design and analysis of algorithms and systems for
that rely on processing human language input.
used in NLP involves several steps. The natural language input for the pipeline discussed in this book is typically
as a collection of machine-readable text documents, known as a
a larger collection of these documents is referred to as
When employing NLP systems, the standard pipeline consists of a sequence of steps, as illustrated in Figure 2.2, to address one or more NLP-based tasks.
Figure 2.2: Stages of the language processing pipeline for textual data input.

Depending upon the task, the output from the NLP pipeline could be in the form of a sentence-level or word-level class label, a sequence of words, a piece of text, and even paths of a graph node-to-edge sequence (
Figure 2.3). To better illustrate the tasks, we will consider an example: ‘
I do not support WHO. They
Below is a non-exhaustive list of popular
Detecting the type and intensity of emotional tone or opinion expressed in some text. Here, the output fr the entire sentence is a label such as positive, negative or neutral. Based on the usage of
the phrase ‘do not support’, we can label the sentiment of the above example as ‘Negative’
Figuring out the grammatical class (noun, pronoun, adjective, adverb
etc.) of each word in a sequence. The output is a sequence of class labels tagged for each word in the sentence. The above example can be tagged as: I
Note that in NLP, we use a diverse set of
Identifying and classifying noun phrases into real-world entities like organi
ation, country, groups, nationality, etc. Here, the output is a label for one or more contiguous words. In our example, the terms ‘WHO’ and ‘Indian’ will be tagged as ‘ORG’ for organi
sentence implies, contradicts, or has nothing to do with the preceding
sentence. The output is a label for the sentence pair. In our example, the premise of ‘underfunding’
Identifying the role of each noun phrase with respect to the predicate of the sentence. The output is a label for a phrase.
Conversion of text from one human language to another. Our example, when translated into
का समर्थन नहीं करता. वे भारतीय बीमािरयों के िलए कम फंड देते हैं।
that still retains the information conveyed. The output is a piece of text that is way shorter in length than the reference.
Providing the correct and concise answer to a user query. The output is a piece of text that mimics human response. Based on our example sentence, we can ask the system, ‘Which country does WHO
and expect the answer to be ‘India’

Filling missing information in a structured knowledge graph by using world knowledge. The output is in the form of an edge that is not in the edge list of a graph. For example, an edge to store or predict can be
To enable a machine to learn from data, the primary requirement is the availability of that data, often obtained through a combination of curation strategies such as
. In most cases, the goal is to gather a large collection of unstructured, free-f
owing text fragments or documents, which may or may not be annotated by a human expert. When machine-readable text is unavailable, such as when scanning text from PDFs,
and text dumps are typically the f

Since most textual data is curated from the web, it typically requires cleaning before further processing. This is because the data might contain markup, special characters, personal information, poorly formatted tags, and other unwanted elements. By
employing regular expressions, handling stray characters, and using dictionaries to correct
. Additionally, the data might be encoded in dif
erent Unicode formats, so appropriate logic must be applied to address such encoding issues.
This step involves breaking the text into smaller units and then normali
ing it using techniques such as lowercasing, stop-word removal, stemming, and lemmati
ation, which will be discussed in this chapter. In certain contexts, digits and punctuation may also be removed if they contribute little to the overall information. It
s crucial to note that there is no one-size-f
ts-all preprocessing technique applicable to all NLP tasks.

Once the text has been preprocessed, we now need to represent the text in a way that a machine can understand. As machines reduce everything into numbers, we build a text representation by encoding it into a numeric vector. In NLP or deep learning, encoding can be considered as a mapping function that takes input in raw human-readable form (text, images, videos) and converts it into numerical vectors for computational methods to be applied to them. However, there can be multiple ways of performing encoding, depending on the task, the
and the computational resources available at hand. This is where feature engineering helps. It helps us

e the essential features and most informative parts of the input and only use those to encode the input so that we can encode maximum information in as little memory as possible. Encoding can be achieved by simple frequency-based heuristics such as one-hot encoding and bag-of-words representation. NLP practitioners these days use probabilistic, neural approaches to learn
, which are representations of words in the feature space. Parallel to encoding, decoding is a map function for converting numerical vectors into human-readable symbols (texts, pixels
Once we have encoded the textual data, it can be passed to any machine learning or deep learning model to learn from the corpus. Irrespective of whether the task is one of NLU or
learning from textual data boils down to sequence

since text can always be represented as a sequence of words/phrases/characters. As NLP-based sequence models aim to learn the ‘hidden/latent language’ (in the vector space) from the input text, they are also called
(LMs). For a long time, neural networks like
sequential data, like text. However, with the introduction of
cant leap in the length and complexity of the textual data that can be
, with transformers becoming the de facto standard in today’s NLP. In the coming chapters, we will introduce dif
erent language models along with the fundamental concepts on which LMs are built.
Once the model is designed, we must assess how ‘good’ a language model is. While classif
cation tasks can be evaluated using existing accuracy and F1-score (macro/micro), newer metrics need to be devised for tasks that involve generating text.
tasks, we typically use Bilingual Evaluation Understudy (BLEU) and Recall-Oriented Understudy for
Evaluation (ROUGE) scores, which capture the lexical and syntactic overlap between the expected and predicted text. Meanwhile, newer semantic measures like
have also been designed. When comparing two LMs themselves, we can employ entropy-based measures like perplexity. We introduce these

helps reduce the signal-to-noise ratio in a text corpus by reducing the redundant concepts present in it. The process allows us to build an optimal vocabulary/lexicon that makes up the language of the corpus. This lexicon def
nes the input and output space for the language model trained on the corpus. Many classical tasks in NLP, like sentiment analysis,
c tasks like medical or legal text analysis, depend upon a lexicon for making sense of the input. For many of these tasks, we prefer to use

that are built up by manually annotating with the help of human experts, automatic extraction using statistical and machine learning techniques or using a hybrid approach. The intuition behind the lexicon also plays a role in the formation of rules and conventions to incorporate new terms like ‘
They can be formed due to the adoption of popular culture, foreign words, compounding, or due to morphological changes.

On the one hand, character-level tokens provide more resilience against spelling errors. On the other hand, it comes at the cost of semantic information. For example, the

Here, practitioners have come up with a
process that is a combination of word and character levels tokens, known as
, which is primarily based on splitting and merging tokens based on the frequency of occurrence within a corpus. In this section, we discuss the two most widely adopted bottom-up
ation techniques that take a greedy approach based on the frequency of
Byte Pair Encoding and Wordpiece Tokeni

Byte pair encoding (Gage 1994) was initially developed as an algorithm to encode/compress a text based on the most frequently occurring bytes (a byte or 8 bits refers to a single character token for practical usage). The algorithm merges the most frequently occurring consecutive bytes and replaces them with a new representative token that is not part of the existing lexicon. The process continues until no more merger is possible (see Algorithm 1).
n order to preserve word boundaries, the space token is replaced by a special token, say
which is not a part of the vocabulary and is concatenated to the last character of each word. Thus, our 2nd and 3rd words in the corpus,

he processing of merging characters in BPE depends solely on the frequency count of the characters at each iteration. Instead of maximi
ing information gain purely based on frequency, we can maximi
e the likelihood of improving the subword’s coverage within the corpus. A famous probabilistic variant of BPE is the WordPiece Tokeni
er. Keeping the rest of the BPE process the same, the primary modif
cation that WordPiece introduces is by replacing the exact frequency count in Algorithm 1 at step 4 with Equation
of the co-occurring pair by the product of individual frequency counts (Equation

es those pairs that are highly frequent in the corpus. In other words, if particular terms are by themselves high frequency, then their combination provides lesser information gain compared to combining less frequent terms.

methods we have examined require the corpus to be split at a word level and be preprocessed at an individual word level, for which the assumption is the language of the corpus contains spaces as delimiters. However, there are some languages, like Chinese or Japanese, in which space delimitation is not available. Thus, a language
agnostic/space-agnostic approach is required. Here, the SentencePiece
comes into play. SentencePiece incorporates a number of techniques to improve upon the existing tokeni

ation setup. SentencePiece employs Unicode Normalization to work with raw texts. It employs heap sort to keep track of the vocabulary size. But most importantly, unlike BPE and WordPiece, which employ a pre-tokeni
ation step (Step 2, Algorithm 1), SentencePiece is capable of working with raw texts.

As per the Oxford Dictionary, the term ‘syntax’ refers to the rules/grammar that state how words are placed and used in a language to form sentences. The syntax is based on the grouping of words in a natural order. An English sentence is composed of a group of words that form the
can be combined as a single noun phrase
’ is the verb phrase. The whole sentence can syntactically be represented as
This process of mapping words and groups of words (phrases) into their grammatical units is called

. While linear representation in terms of rules is a way to decompose the sentence, it can also be represented in the form of a hierarchy or a tree, with the words forming the leave nodes, the grammatical constituents forming the intermediate nodes, and the sentence forming the root node. In this section, we provide an overview of three ways in which the syntax tree can be parsed. The parse trees act as an abstraction of the sentence.
Figure 2.4: Constituent Parsing for the Sentence, ‘
The mouse ate the cheese that was kept in the drawer
tagging and constituency parsing, we implicitly looked at the relation among the words to assign adequate tags and phrases. Still, the information was insuf
cient to answer questions such as
? In such cases, we need to mark the relation between

explicitly. Being able to state the subjects and objects in a sentence, along with the relationship among them, is known as dependency parsing. The dependency grammar describes the structure of a sentence in terms of the
elationship that holds between words. The dependency relations thus act as a proxy to the semantic relations in text. These binary relations consist of a

. The head is the central word in a constituent (e.g., noun in a noun phrase, verb in a verb phrase). All other words are dependent on the head. In a dependency parse tree, the heads are linked to words that are immediately dependent on them. The main verb of the sentence is the root node from which one can follow a unique directed path to each word in the sentence. Such a parse tree is f
exible with word order and is helpful in parsing morphologically rich languages as well. Figure 2.5 shows the parse tree for an example sentence ‘
The mouse ate the cheese that was kept in the drawer
that use stacks to create dependency structures and graph-based methods that use maximum spanning trees.
The dependency parse tree for the sentence, ‘
The mouse ate the cheese that was kept in the drawer
The labels on the arcs are according to Universal Dependency nomenclature for grammatical relations.
In the last section, we saw how grammatical abstractions can help answer simple questions within a sentence.
Which furniture is being referred to
? then the notion of ‘furniture’ and ‘drawer’ being concepts that are close to each other needs to be established.
This idea of establishing closeness of concepts that may linguistically or grammatically not appear close to each other is known as semantic similarity.
ned as the underlying meaning associated with the entity under consideration. Semantics help access what is the relation that di
ferent words have with each other when present together in a sentence. For example, when presented with a
’ depending on the context in which the
is used. The way a language evolves plays a central role in explaining these relations. Here, word association can be def
ned as a relationship between words in a language based on their meaning. Semantics is not just
concerned with the meaning of words but also how to combine words into meaningful phrases and sentences. For example, the phrases
carry the same connotation/semantics even though the terms are lexically di

Semantic parsing involves mapping the natural language input to a logical form that connects the language to real-world concepts. Unlike syntactic parsing methods, which focus solely on structure and grammar, semantic parsing methods try to extract the meaning and context of a sentence. A semantic parser consists of a formal knowledge representation technique and an inference mechanism. One of the ways to represent language formally is by translating a sentence to f
rst-order logic, where the predicates are the words in the sentence. In order to represent the words as predicates, we need to be sure of the

in which the word has been used in the sentence. Even if we can represent words and relationships as predicates, these do not make sense on their own. An external knowledge source is required to help us def
ne rules that use these predicates and learn the semantic logic. In this section, we brief
y describe three techniques for semantic parsing
We can derive the meaning of a word by dividing it into various semantic components or qualities. For instance, in the sentence
mouse ate the cheese that was kept in the drawer’,
it would imply that the subject has all of the three qualities
These decomposed semantics can also be mapped to f
Another way of decomposing the meaning of a word is by studying its relationship to other words. Take the classic example of the word
‘Bank’ itself means a collection or storage. However, what that collection is about
nition that word will semantically adopt. This process of def
ning the existence/usage of a term with respect to a sentence is called
is a famous lexical and ontological resource in English. It contains various kinds of relations that exist between English words. For example, the word
implies that it is a type of
Capturing these relations in the text is crucial to understanding world knowledge.
So far, in our discussion of semantics, we have assumed the computational methods to carry the same level of contextuali
ation as humans. While machines lack subconscious contextuali
ation, they can approximate the same by analy
ing large corpora of text and deriving a sense of words based on their distributional properties (e.g., co-occurrence, frequency). This maps to the law of association that
words with similar distributions might have similar meanings.
For instance, the meaning of the word
may be complex for the machine to grasp, yet it can
inferred from the contexts it appears in,
.e., sentences where it co-occurs with words like ‘
etc. Distributional Semantics forms the core of the modern-day NLP.
According to Herbert Clark, whenever two words occur together or in close proximity, an
is formed between them in our mind over time, and the more frequently they appear together, the stronger the association (Clark 1970).
Building up word association and logic of distributional semantics, we can describe a

as a model that learns the probability distribution over the words in the corpus. This probability is learned based on the frequency co-occurrence of words in a large training corpus. Once trained/learned, the
attempts to predict the next token in a sequence of tokens. For a sequence of
based on the language learned from its training corpus of words and phrases. The output space, i.e., the set of all possible words that can be the (
token in a sequence, is the whole vocabulary/lexicon learned over the language. If the
unique tokens, then in the worst case, each of
tokens has an equal and independent probability of 1
However, from our semantic and syntactic parsing, we know that for a given sentence, not all words have an equal probability of occurrence. Instead, the words that can appear next are
on the words that are present so far in the sentence. It forms the basis of language model
ing in NLP. In layman’s terms, a language model predicts the probability of the (
tokens seen before. Going back to our example sentence, if you are asked to predict the next word in the sequence of ‘
of all the words we know in English (i.e., our vocabulary), the most likely next word should be ‘
’. This likelihood is the probability spread over the whole vocabulary of which ‘
’ has the highest probability score. We will introduce the formal concepts of conditional probability and language model
Forgoing the notion of conditional probability, one can still obtain a crude form of language model

ing that depends solely on the constituted tokens present in the sentence. Let us consider the task of sentiment analysis. A simple method for determining whether a sentence expresses positive sentiment would be to count the favo
rable and negatively connotated lexical terms that occur in the sentence. The process is solely based on the
of individual words and not where and how they appear in the sentence, i.e., the notion of semantics or syntax is overlooked. Such setups are called the
approach, where we know the words in the bag but not the order in which they are placed in the bag.
via a simple example of sentiment classification.
Consider three sentences that represent three samples of sentiment analysis: S1:

Further, each sentence has a sentiment label associated with it where
1 means negative sentiment, 0 means neutral, and 1 means positive. Our example sentences have a sentiment score of S1:
1, S2:v1, and S3: 1, respectively. From the crude analysis of the sentence vectors, we see that tokens ‘

’ occur in all three sentences and do not lead to any differentiation for the sentiment classification, i.e., we cannot tell by looking at only these two terms if the movie is good or bad. Meanwhile, the presence of ‘
’ in S1 and its subsequent absence in S2 and S3 is an indicator of associating the presence of ‘
1. Language models build on bag-of-word representation and try to learn such heuristics between tokens and labels based on the frequency of occurrence of the tokens in different class labels.
The notion of building representations from term frequency is detailed in Chapter 3.

o far, the algorithms we have discussed for parsing and understanding language are based on simple heuristics and probabilities. To develop a more advanced and nuanced understanding of language, we must work with neural networks. This part of the book will help readers establish a basic understanding of computational neural networks. The theoretical foundation for these networks can be traced back to the independent works of Alexander Bain in 1873 and William James in 1890. Both
that human thoughts and decisions emerge from interactions among billions of

in the human brain. This biological network of nerve cells is responsible for all human reasoning and decision-making. Warren McCulloch, a neuroscientist, and Walter Pitts, a logician, laid out a theoretical model for a biological nerve cell in 1943. They called it a
. In 1957, Frank Rosenblatt, a psychologist, provided an early hardware implementation of a perceptron. Rosenblatt took a linear combination of di

ferent input variables and gave a response of 1 or 0, depending on whether the linear combination of input variables was positive or negative. The version of the perceptron we use today was introduced by
in 1969. They introduced the concept of an
, an essential component of all artif

The architecture of computational neural networks is inspired by the nervous system in humans, where a network of neurons is responsible for processing, relaying, storing, and recalling information. A biological neuron receives signals from other neurons and chooses to transfer the processed signals to neighbouring neurons, depending on the outcome of processing. We can replicate the same in software via the
, which is the most straightforward software implementation of a biological neural cell.

We have already described in the gradient descent algorithm in Equation
that prior to weight update, a full pass through the training

is required. In the case of a large number of training samples, it becomes computationally expensive and slow to iterate over all the data samples at once. In order to improve the training process, we use two variants of
This variant of gradient descent allows for the updation of the model parameters after processing a single training example.
This variant allows for faster convergence towards the minima and is less memory-intensive (loads only a single sample to memory at a time) than vanilla gradient descent. However, by

As explained before, the training of a neural network involves processing all the samples in the training
. Once trained (i.e., no more weights are updated), it is imperative to determine how well the model will predict on
on which we evaluate the generali
ability of a trained neural network is called the
Note we assume that both training and testing samples are drawn from the
A neural network model is said to

if it fails to perform well even in the training stage. It can be a result of the smaller number of training samples from which to learn any meaningful patterns or the smaller complexity of the neural network that prevents it from learning more complex patterns within the training
or both. On the contrary, a neural network is said to
if it performs well on the training
but fails to perform on the test set. In such cases, a neural network learns the noisy patterns in the training set, which leads to a lack of generali
Thus, by controlling how complex the network is and conf
we can, in turn, impact the learning process. Such conf
gurable variables (explicitly declared before training) whose value controls the learning process are termed
Based on our understanding of overf
tting, it appears that the model’s complexity plays a vital role in the learning process. But how do we def

ne the complexity of a neural network? In terms of the number of weight multiplication operations that form the basic building block of a neural network, we can control the complexity of the network by capping the number of activation units. Recall the concept of depth and breadth of an

in Figure 2.7. By increasing the depth of the network, we allow the system to model more complex functions. Meanwhile, by increasing the breadth of the network, we can accommodate more feature vectors. Both will enable us to reduce underf
tting. Note that while theoretically, one can have inf
nite depth and breadth, such a system will overf
The ideal number of training iterations/steps is such that any further training provides little to no boost in test accuracy. The number of iterations is also known by the term number of
, where each epoch is complete when all the training samples have been processed.
determines the magnitude of steps taken in the direction of decreasing gradient (Equation

17). A large learning rate implies taking larger strides, which may lead to scenarios where we keep hovering around the local minima without reaching it. In contrast, with a smaller learning rate, it takes too long to reach the optima. There are various strategies that one can use to manage the learning rate during the training of a neural network.
: In this training strategy, the learning rate remains constant throughout the training process.

: In this training strategy, the learning rate decreases proportionally to training steps. It is based on the idea that initially, the model will begin by predicting randomly and have a higher error rate. However, as the training progressed, the error would have reduced.
ation is another set of techniques that can help avoid
: One of the most straightforward techniques to prevent overf
tting is to limit the number of updates made to the weight parameters. Heuristically, if we can avoid the training loss from becoming arbitrarily low, the model will be less likely to overf

When obtaining the derivative of the loss with respect to weights, the
value may be extremely small or large, leading to the problem of vanishing or exploding gradients.

refers to the situation when the gradient information cannot be transferred from the output layers to the hidden layers due to the gradients assuming very small values. Following our previous notation, let
denote the index of the output layer. Then, we calculate the gradient of error term
with respect to weights in different layers of the networks. For the
hidden layer, let us denote the weight parameters as
is the activation function. Note that each hidden layer would have multiple hidden units, but we do not label such hidden units to avoid complications.
is from the output layer (deeper the neural network), the more terms of the form incorporating the partial derivative of the hidden unit with respect to the activation appear.
It so happens that these derivatives assume very low values for activation functions like sigmoid and tanh. ReLU activation is usually employed when there is a risk of a vanishing gradient problem.
On the opposite spectrum is the problem where large error gradients accumulate and result in huge updates to neural network model weights during training. These may occur due to lousy
of weights or some combinations of activation functions.
Once we have optimally trained our neural network, we need to be able to report how
the model is performing. Additionally, given that for a given set of input and target values, multiple
weights can be obtained. How do we determine which set of weights are the best for an unseen
Let us go back to the task of sentiment analysis. Suppose we have ten sentences
as either positive (1) or negative (–1). Out of these, seven samples are label
ed as positive. Let us assume an arbitrary target label list for the ten samples as
element of the list providing a sentiment label for the
How many times did we correctly predict the positive sentiment?
How many times did we incorrectly predict positive sentiments as negative?
How many times did we incorrectly predict negative sentiments as positive?
How many times did we correctly predict the negative sentiment?
Case 1 of the confusion matrix can also be termed as
as we are truly/correctly predicting the positive class as positive. Consequently, case 4 is termed as
as we truthfully predict the negative class as negative.

Looking only at the predictions that are marked as positive, precision measures the number of times the predictions were actually correct, as actualised by Equation
) sentiments for ten sentences. We construct this from expected labels
. The tabulations follow from mapping in Table 2.9.
On the other hand, looking at the actual/expected positive samples, recall measures the number of times we correctly predicted the positive class.
The confusion matrix can be mapped using
that the main difference in precision and recall is dictated by the type of erroneous outputs that are accounted for. In the case of precision, we place higher importance on

Consider the case of spam detection. If the emails keep getting falsely classified as safe/positive, then the user will be inundated with spam instead of useful information. Meanwhile, in the case of a recall, we place higher importance on
Consider the case of medical testing, where a positive test means a disease is detected. Failing to detect the disease
when it should have been positive) can cost human life. In any given experimental setup, precision and recall will be a tug-of-war, as reducing
and vice-versa, and which metric is
depends on the task at hand.
For most use cases, we rather prefer to look at a single metric that considers both precision and recall. Here,
F1 score comes into play. It is simply a harmonic mean of precision and recall as follows:
Another advantage of the F1 score over other metrics is its ability to account for class imbalance, therefore providing a more holistic measure of model performance.

In this chapter, we explored some of the fundamental concepts of NLP and neural networks necessary for understanding the more advanced topics covered later in the book. We began by discussing the motivation behind processing information conveyed through natural language, focusing on how a word is structured using morphological knowledge. We then reviewed the essential steps of the NLP pipeline and examined various
. Additionally, we explored the syntax and semantics of language before introducing core ideas related to language models and word/sentence representation techniques.

-dimensional feature vectors for sentiment analysis, we introduced the concept of neural networks. Given that neural networks are the foundation of modern NLP, this chapter provided an overview of the fundamental aspects of neural networks. We discussed perceptrons and their limitations, which led to the development of multi-layer perceptrons and the concept of deep neural networks. The chapter also covered training neural networks via backpropagation, the basics of activation functions, and the role of various

that can impact the training process. Furthermore, we outlined scenarios where a model might encounter vanishing or exploding gradient problems and how these issues can be mitigated. The chapter concluded with an introduction to evaluation metrics commonly used in classification tasks.
In the following chapters, we will build upon the concepts of word associations, neural networks, and
-grams to develop more sophisticated representations and language models that go beyond the bag-of-words approach.
